'''Bobby Murray''' (born June 9, 1953) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] guitarist, songwriter and record producer. Murray has played in [[Etta James]]' backing band for twenty years, performed on three [[Grammy Award]] winning recordings with James and [[B.B. King]], and released three solo [[album]]s. In 2011, the Detroit Blues Society granted Murray their Lifetime Achievement Award.

His guitar playing was mainly influenced by [[Albert Collins]]. Murray currently resides in [[Ferndale, Michigan]], [[United States]].<ref name="Tribune"/>

==Life and career==
Murray was born in [[Nagoya]], [[Japan]], to an [[Irish people|Irish]] father and a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] mother.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=pbobby-murray-p108438/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Bobby Murray|author=Richard Skelly |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=December 20, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Tribune">{{cite news |url=http://www.dailytribune.com/articles/2011/01/20/entertainment/doc4d38586393e38238689474.txt |title=Blues musicians Bobby Murray, Willie D. Warren honored |author=Joe Ballor |date=January 20, 2011 |work= |publisher=Dailytribune.com |accessdate=December 20, 2011}}</ref> Growing up in a military family setting, he was later raised in [[Tacoma, Washington]].<ref name="Take"/> Murray attended the same [[high school]] as [[Robert Cray]], and they engaged [[Albert Collins]] to play at the school's graduation party.<ref name="AMG"/>

He started his musical career playing in the blues [[nightclub|clubs]] in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]],<ref name="AMG"/> having originally formed an ensemble that became Robert Cray and the Crayolas.<ref name="Tribune"/>  Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, Murray supplied guitar backing for [[Frankie Lee (musician)|Frankie Lee]] and [[Sonny Rhodes]]. He also at various times appeared on the same stage as Albert Collins, [[Charlie Musselwhite]], [[Otis Rush]], [[Jimmy Witherspoon]], and [[John Lee Hooker]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Take"/> In 1988, he was invited to join [[Etta James]]' backing ensemble, the Roots Band.<ref name="AMG"/> Murray has worked with her for more than two decades.<ref name="Tribune"/> His other playing and recording duties have seen Murray work with [[Albert King]], [[Johnny "Guitar" Watson]], [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]], [[Percy Mayfield]], [[Sugar Pie DeSanto]], and [[Lowell Fulson]].<ref name="Tribune"/>

He appeared on [[B.B. King]]'s Grammy Award recognised album, ''[[Blues Summit]]'', where he again teamed up with Cray on the track, "Playing With My Friends."<ref name="AMG"/>  Murray also played guitar on James' Grammy winning recordings, ''[[Let's Roll (album)|Let's Roll]]'' and ''[[Blues to the Bone]]''.<ref name="Take">{{cite web |url=http://www.takezomusic.com/bobby_bio.htm |title=Bobby Murray's All-Star Review |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Takezomusic.com |accessdate=December 20, 2011}}</ref> In addition, Murray played on the Etta James song, "Blues is My Business", which was used in the [[television program|television drama series]], ''[[The Sopranos]]''.<ref name="Tribune"/> 

Through his work with James, Murray appeared on other television programs such as ''[[The Tonight Show]]'', ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' and ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]''.  On stage he played at the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] in [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]], the [[World of Music, Arts and Dance|WOMAD Festival]], and the inaugural celebration for [[Bill Clinton]] being elected as the [[List of Presidents of the United States|42nd President of the United States]].<ref name="Tribune"/>

Murray's debut album, ''The Blues is Now'' (1996), featured Frankie Lee and Freddie Hughes on vocals.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Is Now">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=the-blues-is-now-r231550|pure_url=yes}}|title=''The Blues is Now'' > Bobby Murray > Overview |accessdate=December 20, 2011 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> The [[Allmusic]] journalist, Thom Owens, commented about Murray's work on the recording, "he's a fine guitarist, as he proves here, turning out jazzy, classy solos that separate him from the rest of the crowd."<ref name="Is Now"/> In 1999, the follow-up album, ''Waiting for Mr. Goodfingers...'', was issued by No Cover Productions.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=waiting-for-mr-goodfingers-r563286|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Waiting for Mr. Goodfingers...'' > Bobby Murray  > Overview |accessdate=December 20, 2011|publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>  A [[live album]], ''Live & Lowdown!'' was released in May 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=live--lowdown-r1048239|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Live & Lowdown!'' > Bobby Murray  > Overview |accessdate=December 20, 2011|publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>

In May 2010, the Bobby Murray Band played at the [[Scarab Club]] in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://crossharpchronicles.wordpress.com/2010/05/09/the-bobby-murray-band-wsgs-lenny-watkins-and-robert-penn-to-appear-at-the-scarab-club-detroit-blues-heritage-series-event-2-may-22/ |title=Scarab Club Detroit Blues Heritage Series - Event 2, Featuring the Bobby Murray Band, May 22, 2010 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Crossharpchronicles.wordpress.com |accessdate=December 20, 2011}}</ref>

In 2011, the Detroit Blues Society gave Murray a Lifetime Achievement Award, alongside a separate posthumous creditation for [[Willie D. Warren]].
